For effective memorization of information, a person created mnemonics. The word "mnemonic" is derived from the Ancient Greek word μνημονικός (mnēmonikos), meaning "of memory, or relating to memory" \n \nMind Palace will help you master this art. The basics In the Mind Palace, there are 4 types of associative groups: \n \n • Number; \n • Dates; \n • Text; \n • Link. \n \n Each group has its own characteristics. You can select the appropriate one in the group settings. After creating a group, you need to create your own associations. And then start learning them. The learning When you have at least 10 associations, you can start studying them. The learning process is based on the forgetting Curve (Ebbinghaus curve), i.e., the repetition of the material at certain intervals. \"Repetition\" is independent and error-free reproduction of information. \"%1$s\"- current status of the Association;\n\"%2$d\" - number of repetitions;\n"%3$s\ " - time of the next repetition. After the 4th successful repetition of at least 10 associations, you will be able to pass the exam to confirm that you have learned them. Forgetting curve Our brain erases unnecessary information for itself, so that this does not happen, you need to \"explain\" to the brain that this information is important. To do this, repeat the information at the following intervals: 30 min -> 2 hours -> 8 hours -> 32 hours - > 5 days - > 20 days - > 80 days, etc. These boundaries are the minimum period between repetitions. You can move them up to 50%. In the first hour, up to 60% of the information is forgotten, i.e. only 40% remains in memory, and in 10 hours - 35%. Then forgetting slows down, after 6 days there is 20%, and the same amount remains in a month.
